issue.body:
In the curl tool.

To enable:
- autotools: `--enable-ca-native-by-default`
- cmake: `-DCURL_CA_NATIVE_BY_DEFAULT=ON`
- CPPFLAGS: `-DCURL_CA_NATIVE_BY_DEFAULT`

When enabled, consider disabling implicit on-disk CA bundles, to avoid
auto-loading potentially outdated, redundant bundles from unsafe, 
world-writable, paths:
- autotools: `--disable-ca-search`
- cmake: `-DCURL_DISABLE_CA_SEARCH=ON`
- CPPFLAGS: `-DCURL_DISABLE_CA_SEARCH`

When enabled, native CA can be disabled at run-time with
the `--no-ca-native` and/or `--no-proxy-ca-native` command-line options.

Rationale: This build option:
- has a repeat and active interest from packagers and users.
- helps integrating curl with Windows for those who need this.
- may also apply to macOS: #17525
- makes it trivial to use custom certs configured on the OS.
- frees applications/packagers/users from the task of securely
  distributing, and keeping up-to-date, a CA bundle.
- frees potentially many curl tool users from configuring a CA bundle
  manually to access HTTPS (and other TLS) URLs. This is traditionally
  difficult on Windows because there is no concept of a universal,
  protected, non-world-writable, location on the file system to securely
  store a CA bundle.
- allows using modern features regardless of Windows version. Some of
  these features are not supported with Schannel (e.g. HTTP/3, ECH) on
  any Windows version.
- is necessary for HTTP/3 builds, where bootstrapping a CA bundle is not
  possible with Schannel, because MultiSSL is not an option, and HTTP/3
  is not supported with Schannel.

Ref: #16181 (previous attempt)
Ref: https://github.com/curl/curl/discussions/9348
Ref: https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/9350
Ref: https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/13111
Ref: https://github.com/microsoft/vcpkg/pull/46459#issuecomment-3162068701
Ref: 22652a5a4cb6a4cc1c0f4ff3ebc4f9768f6663cd #14582

body: You mean the fallback? Yes, the underlying crypto framework knows best where to search for the system trust. Moreover, all ports on FreeBSD using OpenSSL use `SSL_CTX_set_default_verify_paths()`. OpenSSL is then configured accordingly. No needle to fiddle with every port. Ideally, this would rather be `--with-native-ca`.

> this would rather be --with-native-ca.

We have traditionally considered "native" to be the CA stores that are tied to the system in the way macOS and Windows do it, so that there's a difference between using a CA cert bundle and the native.

On Linux, BSD etc when the system already uses a CA bundle, there's really no point in seeing it as native vs not native I think.

> > this would rather be --with-native-ca.
> 
> We have traditionally considered "native" to be the CA stores that are tied to the system in the way macOS and Windows do it, so that there's a difference between using a CA cert bundle and the native.
> 
> On Linux, BSD etc when the system already uses a CA bundle, there's really no point in seeing it as native vs not native I think.

I don't disagree, but I'd even abstract from that. The actual on-disk format doesn't really matter as long as the crypto lib is able to access it. Consider it opaque to you. This suffices my understanding of "native". Both wolfSSL and GnuTLS do the same magic in the source code as OpenSSL does with the fallback. I see no reason why the `openssl.c` should not have "native" for non-Windows and "fallback" removed at some point.
